item.title: Online Stores Beat Brick-And-Mortar In Customer Service
item.description: Online shoppers are more satisfied with customer service than their counterparts at brick-and-mortar stores, a survey shows.

item.title: File-Sharing Company Signs Three Major Music Labels
item.description: Wurld Media says three of the four major music labels have agreed to have their catalogs distributed over the company's peer-to-peer digital file-sharing network.

item.title: USDA Searches Web For Clues About Illegal Plants And Animals
item.description: It's deploying new search software that more intelligently finds sites that trade in flora and fauna that could harm people or the U.S. ecology.

item.title: E-Mail And IM Get Closer
item.description: ICQ and Mail2World collaboration shows that E-mail and IM services are converging.

item.title: Bot Networks Behind Big Boost In Phishing Attacks
item.description: Phishing fraudsters dramatically anted up last month by using automated tools and networks of hacked computers.

item.title: Vendors Aim To Ease Compliance For Web Data
item.description: Filtering appliance vendor 8e6 Technologies and storage vendor Procom ally to let companies better manage their Web data for compliance purposes.

item.title: ID Theft Nightmares Frighten E-Shoppers, Survey Says
item.description: Nearly six in every ten consumers say they may cut back on clicking this holiday season because they're worried about identity theft while they e-shop, a survey says.

item.title: 5.6 Million Choose Firefox In First Two Weeks
item.description: More than 5.6 million copies of the Firefox 1.0 stand-alone browser have been downloaded in the first two weeks of its release, the Mozilla Foundation says.

item.title: Opera Claims It Solves Device Web Display Issues
item.description: Norwegian browser vendor says its new technology renders pages clearly on screens of all sizes.

item.title: Apparel Industry Catches Up To Supply-Chain Age
item.description: For an industry that makes its money by being ahead of everyone else, few have modernized the all-important supply chain. Koret is one that has invested, however.

item.title: IP VPN Equipment Market Reaches $267 Million
item.description: Edge routers are a particularly hot product, says report, representing 51% of total IP VPN equipment sales.

item.title: AOL Co-Founder Case Takes Over Exclusive Resorts LLC
item.description: Former America Online Chairman Steve Chase has purchased a majority stake in luxury travel company, Exclusive Resorts LLC.

item.title: Firefox Gains, IE Slides
item.description: Microsoft's stranglehold on the browser market continues to loosen, a Dutch Web monitoring company says as it released new numbers that show the open-source Firefox making inroads.

item.title: Ad Banner Attack Involved Comedy Central
item.description: More details came to light Tuesday about the weekend attack that compromised a German Web advertising company's server and infected users who visited Web sites run by the firm's clients with the MyDoom/Bofra worm.

item.title: Java Bug Makes IE, Firefox Vulnerable
item.description: A flaw in Sun's Java Virtual Machine can open up the two most popular browsers, Microsoft's Internet Explorer and Mozilla's Firefox, to attack, security exeprts say.

item.title: SBC Installs Wireless Internet in Barnes & Nobles Stores
item.description: SBC Communications launches Wi-Fi services at more than 600 Barnes & Noble bookstores nationwide.

item.title: WiFi Hardware Sales Jump 9% Over Last Year
item.description: Sales of WiFi switches boom 80%; Cisco remains overall WiFi market leader.

item.title: Online Merchants Fight The Good Fight Against Fraud
item.description: Merchants have increased methods for combating online fraud by 13% compared with last year. Address-verification systems and customer follow-up top the list.

item.title: DoubleClick Predicts More Online Holiday Spending
item.description: An online survey of e-commerce buyers revealed that more shoppers plan to make online purchases during the upcoming holiday season than they did last year.

item.title: Microsoft, Time Warner, Thomson Partner In Anti-Piracy Software Firm
item.description: French technology company Thomson has agreed to join Microsoft and Time Warner as a partner in ContentGuard, a move expected to ease European regulators' concerns over Microsoft's involvement in the anti-piracy software company.

item.title: Hacked European Ad Server Infects IE Users
item.description: A hacked server in Germany fed malicious code to unsuspecting Internet Explorer users at an unknown number of Web sites for several hours over the weekend.

item.title: Kazaa 3.0 Includes P2P Internet Phone Service
item.description: Kazaa, one of the most popular file sharing programs, revved to version 3.0, adding an integrated peer-to-peer (P2P) Internet phone service.

item.title: Internet Telephony Growth Drives VoIP Gear Market
item.description: The growing momentum of Internet telephoning is driving a boom in VoIP gear, which jumped 69 percent, to $452 million, in the third quarter, according to a report released Monday by Infonetics Research.

item.title: Qwest extends Abilene contract for Internet2
item.description: Qwest extends Abilene contract for Internet2

item.title: Malicious Trojan Identified For Nokia Smartphones
item.description: Trojan is disguised as downloadable shareware and replaces applications with non-functional versions.

item.title: Online Retailers Better Prepared For Holiday Shopping
item.description: Online-retail sites this year seem better prepared for the holiday shopping season, as they benefit from the increasing number of U.S. homes with high-speed connections and adopt the tactics of brick-and-mortar stores in driving traffic, experts said Tuesday.

item.title: AOL Tests New Netscape Browser
item.description: America Online Inc. on Tuesday started testing a prototype of the Netscape browser that lets users switch from the Mozilla rendering engine to Internet Explorer with the click of a button.

item.title: Unprotected PCs Fall To Hacker Bots In Just Four Minutes
item.description: The lifespan of a poorly protected PC connected to the Internet is a mere four minutes, research released Tuesday claimed. After that, it's owned by a hacker.

item.title: 'Blog' Is Word Of The Year
item.description: "Blog" is the Word of the Year, dictionary publisher Merriam-Webster said Tuesday, as it released the year's top 10 words keyed in by users searching its Web sites.

item.title: Phishers Take Aim At EarthLink, Other ISPs
item.description: Phishers are widening their nets to include customers of Internet service providers (ISP), a security firm said Tuesday after analyzing a campaign against the Atlanta-based ISP, EarthLink.

item.title: Lycos Strikes Back At Spammers With DoS Screensaver
item.description: Lycos Europe took the fight to the enemy Monday, by launching a screensaver that conducts a group denial-of-service (DoS) attacks against sites selling products marketed via spam.

item.title: WLAN Security Market Heats Up With Product Launches
item.description: Highwall Technologies and AirTight Networks both release tools for securing Wi-Fi networks.

item.title: Homeland Security Network Advances Even As Congress Intelligence Bill Stalls
item.description: The Homeland Security Department is making progress on its 'network of networks' for information sharing, moving into the testing and accreditation phase.

item.title: Online Shopping Has Its Brightest 'Black Friday'
item.description: More people than ever chose to let their fingers do their holiday shopping. Consumers spent $250 million online on Friday, a 41% increase over the $174 million they spent online on the same day a year ago,

item.title: Computer Firms Score Poorly In Privacy, Customer Response
item.description: Companies are slow to answer online customer inquries, and more than a third share customer data with others without permission, study says.

item.title: Register.com Enters Online Backup Race
item.description: Domain-name registration firm Register.com Monday added online backup to its list of services, targeting one-person and small-business Web sites.

item.title: Blue Day For Blu-ray: Movie Studios Back Toshiba's HD-DVD
item.description: A group of movie studios threw support Monday behind Toshiba Corp.'s high-definition HD-DVD format and, thereby, drew a line in the sand against Sony Corp.'s competing next- generation Blu-ray DVD technology.

item.title: Microsoft WINS Said To Be Vulnerable
item.description: Microsoft said Sunday it's looking into reports of a security screw-up in Windows Internet Name Service (WINS), a component of its most popular server software, including Windows NT 4.0 Server, Windows 2000 Server, and Windows Server 2003.

item.title: Catch of the Day: Banks Face New Phishing Scams
item.description: Newer and more intelligent phishing attacks target bank customers globally.

item.title: 802.11 Standard Modified For Japan
item.description: The IEEE approves IEEE 802.11j spec to enable the development of Japan-enabled WLAN equipment.

item.title: SCO Group Web Site Attacked Again
item.description: Pages were defaced with text that erroneously implied that SCO would sue Microsoft for intellectual-property theft.

item.title: New Charges Against Kazaa: 'Pirate' And 'Pest'
item.description: Peer-to-peer pacesetter Kazaa was the subject to two unfavorable allegations Monday--one in an Australian court, where it was labeled a pirate; the other in a report from Computer Associates, calling Kazaa the leading spyware pest.

item.title: Global Crossing Offers New SLAs For Its High-Performance IP Network
item.description: Company offers new guarantees for converged IP services, including VoIP, IP video, and IP VPN.

item.title: Get The Right Info
item.description: FullTilt Solutions' system manages product info and online catalog more efficiently
